awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Tradeoffs between specialist and generalist strategies for host immune evasion in a vector-borne bacterium
awd_abstract_narration:
This research addresses a unique example of how the environment can impact human and animal health by shaping bacterial communities in nature. Microbes causing human or animal disease differ in the number of hosts they can infect; while some specialize on a single animal/plant, others are able to infect a wide range. Specialist organisms may be better able to escape the host immune system and thus survive, but they risk becoming extinct if the host becomes rare. Pathogens with wide host ranges are often better able to 'jump' to new hosts, driving epidemics. This award will investigate how Borrelia burgdorferi - the bacterium that causes Lyme disease - escapes killing by the immune system of its natural host and whether different genetic types of this bacterium are uniquely adapted to mammals versus birds in nature. This award will also investigate whether Borrelia diversity is explained by adaptation to different hosts or, alternatively, by the targeting of the most common strains by host antibodies, allowing coexistence of rarer strains. Borrelia diversity directly impacts human health because strains cause differential disease severity. This award will increase knowledge about how ecology and evolution of microbes impacts human health.  It will develop educational materials and expand outreach into communities about the links between the environment and human health. In addition, it will provide extensive and interdisciplinary training, at all educational levels, in the fields of disease ecology, molecular ecology and eco-epidemiology.

This award will determine the extent of specialization and immune-mediated competition among strains of B. burgdorferi in different ecological contexts and test the hypothesis that these phenotypic traits are important drivers of B. burgdorferi diversity, community structure and host specialization evolution. While there is evidence of differential B. burgdorferi host association which could drive genetic polymorphisms ('multiple niche polymorphism'), other studies claim that immune-mediated balancing selection acting on one or more B. burgdorferi outer surface proteins can maintain the observed polymorphisms without invoking directional processes ('negative frequency-dependent selection'). This award will disentangle the contribution of multiple mechanisms to B. burgdorferi diversity by assessing strain prevalence in multiple host species by applying deep amplicon sequencing to data from a 6-year-long study in a simplified host community. The physiological basis of host specificity will be explored by evaluating in vitro survival of B. burgdorferi strains when exposed to immune components in serum of different local hosts. Host-specificity related fitness and immune-mediated competition between strains will be assessed with in vivo transmission experiments. The processes by which host specialization and immune-mediated competition determine strain diversity and evolution in different ecological contexts will be examined using novel mathematical models. This study will provide strong evidence of the nature of B. burgdorferi adaptations to avoid the immune system of its natural hosts. It will determine whether these adaptations are species-specific and identify the consequences of host specificity on the structure and diversity of B. burgdorferi strain community. The award will provide multi-disciplinary training to graduate students, including under-represented minorities, and postdoctoral fellows in disease ecology and modeling. To broaden the impact of the work, researchers will leverage contacts with local environmental groups to conduct outreach within the local community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This study investigates the tradeoffs in generalist-specialist host exploitation strategies among the strains of a tick-borne bacterium, Borrelia burgdorferi sensu stricto (hereafter Bb), the etiological agent of Lyme disease in North America. Bb diversified into many genotypically-diverse strains, and genotypes differ in their ability to infect and sustain infection in avian and mammalian hosts. We hypothesized that host specialization is an important driver of Bb diversity and community structure. We assessed this hypothesis by identifying the cellular and immunological mechanisms that facilitate host specialization; defining molecular determinants of host exploitation and immunological competition in a tractable, species-poor host community; and exploring the eco-evolutionary mechanisms shaping host preference in vector-borne disease systems. Key achievements and outcomes of our research include: 

Intellectual Merit

 Our multidisciplinary work provides novel insights into the functional evolution of host-adapted phenotypes, provides mechanistic insights into how a single, short pathogen protein motif can greatly impact host tropism and generates novel insights into the evolutionary and ecological processes governing host competence and the transmission of more severe human pathogenic genotypes in reservoir hosts. By combining insights from laboratory and field experiments, we developed a mechanistic conceptual framework on the role of host specialization, immune cross-reaction, and the composition of communities of co-circulating Borrelia strains. Key findings include: Bb ospC genotypes exhibit variable host breadth and host specificity phenotypes across small mammals and passerine birds (two common reservoir host groups); host-adapted phenotypes among Bb strains are linked to polymorphic loci that confer complement evasion traits in a host-specific manner; host mechanisms conferring host specialization include complement, antibody responses, and inflammatory cytokines as host determinants; the evolutionary history of ospC loci is correlated with host-specific complement-evasion phenotypes; comparative genomics suggests that several gene families and loci are potentially involved in host association; CspZ variants differ in human Factor H-binding ability. Finally, we established two laboratory animal models, Mus musculus (house mice) and Coturnix coturnix (common quail), to recapitulate the findings in nature using reservoir hosts, allowing us to examine further the underlying mechanisms of host specialization. Thus, our study builds a solid foundation for further investigation of the immunological and genomic determinants of host association. 

 

Broader Impacts

A pathogen’s host exploitation strategies have implications for public health since they predict the range of hosts the pathogen can infect, including spillover to humans. Particularly for the Lyme disease bacteria, host adaptation can impact the frequency of genetic variants circulating in nature that have differing human pathogenicity. Thus, the association between Bb eco-evolutionary dynamics and the epidemiology of Lyme disease can provide significant and potentially actionable information to the medical and public health fields. Our research resulted in  9  interdisciplinary publications with 5  more in review or revision, and it resulted in more than 20 presentations in which we disseminated our results to the public, academic, and public health practitioner audiences. The award provided multidisciplinary training to multiple undergraduate, and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, including under-represented minorities, in the fields of disease ecology, molecular ecology, eco-epidemiology,  infectious disease epidemiology and dynamic modeling, evolutionary genomics, and microbial pathogenesis.
